:::{.notes}

Last year in May we held a workshop with ARDC to explore the role of research infrastructure in supporting environmental indicators in Australia.

We identifieed  a strategic opportunity to elevate environmental indicators from static reporting tools to dynamic instruments for foresight and planning. 

Using robust and validated indicators to assess current biodiversity and ecosystem condition and to model future scenarios can lead to more proactive, data-driven policy and decision-making. 

This approach not only fulfils international and national reporting obligations but also empowers long-term environmental
stewardship through targeted actions that build resilience.

Achieving this requires sustained support to advance scientific knowledge, develop new methods, and deliver outputs in
forms that end users can readily adopt. 

Environmental Indicators Initiative
https://ardc.edu.au/project/environmental-indicators-initiative/

National-Scale Integrated Datasets and Services: https://ardc.edu.au/program/national-scale-integrated-datasets-and-services/

:::

## {.smaller}

Australia's diverse ecosystems require tailored indicators for monitoring, assessment, and management.

### F2.5 

F2.5 Ephemeral freshwater lakes, e.g. Menindee Lakes, Lake Cowal, Peery Lake, etc.

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}

<a title="NASA&#039;s Earth Observatory, CC BY 2.0 &lt;https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/2.0&gt;, via Wikimedia Commons" href="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Menindee_Lakes,_New_South_Wales,_Australia_-_NASA_Earth_Observatory.jpg"><img width="512" alt="A system of ephemeral, freshwater lakes which are fed by overflow of the Darling River in Australia" src="img/F2_5.jpg"></a>

::: {.column width="60%"}

*Key processes*: Water volume-chemistry interactions & trophic web, river inflows

*Key threats*: Water extraction, water pollution, eutrophication, climate change

:::

### M1.1

M1.1 Seagrass meadows, e.g. Shark Bay in Western Australia


:::: {.columns}

*Key threats*: Sedimentation, eutrophication, climate change

### T2.5 

T2.5 Temperate pyric humid forest: Alpine Ash forests, Jillaga ash, Blue mnts ash, White ash forests, ...

:::: {.columns}

<a data-flickr-embed="true" data-header="true" data-footer="true" href="https://www.flickr.com/photos/nicholasjones/16653543556" title="Mountain Ash of the Black Spur Drive"><img src="https://live.staticflickr.com/8648/16653543556_a498546030_w.jpg" width="400" height="267" alt="Mountain Ash of the Black Spur Drive"/></a><script async src="//embedr.flickr.com/assets/client-code.js" charset="utf-8"></script>

*Key threats*: Logging & fire regime shift, climate change

### T1.1 

T1.1 Tropical-subtropical lowland rainforest, e.g. Gondwana rainforests, warm temperate rainforests, ...


:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}

*Key threats*: Climate change, fire regime shifts, invasive species, logging legacies

T5.1 Semi-desert steppe: Chenopod shrublands, Bluebush sandplains, Hay plain, Stony downs

*Key threats*: Soil degradation, nutrient flux, land use change

::: notes

This is all very abstract, but let me illustrate this. If somebody in Australia wants to know about a particular species they can go to ALA and find all the information they need. 

Imagine a similar knowledge portal for ecosystems, where users can browse ecosystem classification, explore maps of their distribution, download images, and learn about key processes and threats, etc. 

Particularly we would like to have tools that allow user to identify ecosystem and models that display the functional links between biotic and abiotic features. 


:::

# Aims & Impacts

## Aims & Impacts

A framework for developing fit-for-purpose ecosystem-specific indicators

::: {style="background:#e8fef3; padding:1rem; border-radius:12px;"}
- Design modular, transparent, and reproducible workflow adaptable to:
  - Different datasets  
  - Ecosystem types  
  - Policy and reporting needs  
:::

::: {style="background:#eef1ff; padding:1rem; border-radius:12px;"}
Transparent, defensible, scientifically rigorous indicators
:::

## Aims & Impacts

A community of practice for collaboration & skill sharing 

::: {style="background:#e8fef3; padding:1rem; border-radius:12px;"}
- Support users with different expertise through guided examples.
- Foster a *community of practice* for collaboration and coâ€‘development.
:::
::: {style="background:#eef1ff; padding:1rem; border-radius:12px;"}
Increase capacity and empower the user community
:::

## Aims & Impacts

Accelerate development of fit-for-purpose ecosystem-specific indicators.

::: {style="background:#e8fef3; padding:1rem; border-radius:12px;"}
- Enable scalable, adaptable ecosystem-specific indicator development.
- Track progress across hierarchical levels of ecosystem classification.
